Index

Last Updated: 2025-10-08

Hi, I’m Victoria. Welcome to my page!

I am a Doctoral Student at McGill University who possesses a broad skillset and believes in applying a comprehensive and inclusive approach to research. My passion is to generate practical and applicable knowledge about aquatic invasive species that contributes to positive ecological and legislative change.

My current focus is on understanding and addressing the decline of freshwater biodiversity by examining the impacts of biological invasions. I look at the where, why, and how of invasive crayfishes in the Great Lakes and St Lawrence basin using field, lab, and modeling techniques. I work closely with my supervisor Dr. Anthony Ricciardi and my network of talented colleagues.

You can keep up with my most recent updates in the News roll below. For all other information, please explore the other tabs on this site.

Please feel free to contact me at:

victoria.vanmierlo{-at-}mail.mcgill.ca

News

Aug 28, 2025 - Victoria successfully completed her 1st PhD field season! Check out the gallery for highlights including a rare and beautiful blue color morph of (Faxonius virilis).

March 3, 2025 - New publication alert! “Bioclimatic, terrain, and specific peatland composition are major drivers of woodland caribou winter habitat suitability in northern Ontario” by McFarlane et al. 

November 12, 2024 - Victoria attended the 2024 Dean of Graduate and Postdoctoral Studies’ reception to celebrate Fellowship Award recipients. See the gallery page for photos and more details!

September 3, 2024 - Victoria moved to Montreal and started her PhD at McGill University in the Anthony Ricciardi Lab.

July 15, 2024 - Victoria was awarded a 2024/25 Richard H. Tomlinson Doctoral Fellowship by the McGill Graduate and Postdoctoral Studies Fellowships Committee. She is humbled and honored to have been selected as a Tomlinson Scholar and is excited to join the esteemed line of researchers supported by this award. See her Tomlinson Scholar profile here.

April 25, 2024 - Victoria was awarded the Canada Graduate Scholarship-Doctoral (CGS D) by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC). She is immensely grateful to the council for their support of her and her PhD research at McGill University.
